1042140056612261888.text:
- The contradictions you allow and the contradictions you stamp out
- The exceptions you make and the things that never budge
- Who sits together and how you arrange your office

(4/4)  #culture

1042140052392833025.text:
- When you encourage conformity, and when you promote diversity
- How you handle disagreements and differences in opinion
- How and where you spend your time and money
- What gets discussed out in the open, and behind closed doors

(3/4)  #culture

1042140051134541824.text:
- Who you hire, promote, and compensate, and who you fire
- Who you “smoke out” until they leave the organization
- The worst behavior you accept and the best behavior you reject
- The voices you amplify, and the voices you suppress

(2/4)  #culture

1042140048739598336.text:
Company Culture Is ... 

- What you say, and how often you say it
- What, when, and how you celebrate
- The losses and missteps you acknowledge, and how you respond
- How you behave when the chips are down
- What you fight for at all costs
- The corners you cut

(1/4) #culture

1117453221142966273.text: I completely agree (see my other tweet with the details of the exploit path via 3rd party dependencies)

1117452858599858176.text:
It is every worse (and more realistic) for this to happen via backdoors placed in popular (or just used) dependencies (from pip, npm, or nuget) that are triggered by a special 'signature' 

i.e. the SR (Stay Resident) payload could be activated via a request parameter

1117452055378104321.text:
I completely disagree that is 100% desired behaviour :)

for example a lambda that is doing image processing using a C++ library which happens to have an RCE buffer overflow

When that is exploited (with payload), all further requests that hit that 'reused' env would be affected

This is the part that is not accurate today ( in April 2019)

Great article by @ben11kehoe on the new Google Cloud Run https://read.acloud.guru/the-good-and-the-bad-of-google-cloud-run-34455e673ef5 … but there one big mistake on it. 

At least at the moment, Lamdas are not 100% independent.

AWS reuses Lambdas containers in multiple requests, which could have massive security implications

1071520375924801536.text:
it is not cost, it is the commoditization of the capability

HP, Dell or even Cisco could had been players if they had the innovation speed of AWS, in order to add  instrumentation and automation capabilities to the hardware that they sell

1071521359140933633.text:
I view serverless as an natural evolution/refactoring of the development stack. 

the reason why is so powerful is due to the network effects that it promotes (as in isolated reusable components)

the key concept that really clicked for me was the 'financial mapping' of functions

1071522144159444992.text:
btw, every powerful revolution/change always starts in edge cases :)

the question is if it will 'gain speed as it gains adoption' or if will slow down due to the effects of diminishing returns

1071523499267801089.text:
btw, one of the big missed opportunities today is the blind spot with 'legacy applications'

there will be big rewards for companies that are able to find effective models to refactor/evolve 'legacy code" into 'modern code'

"Today's Lambda functions are Tomorrow's Legacy"

Here is how I ended up mounting an 800Gb SSD drive, from EC2 powerful instance, into the /tmp folder:

sudo mkfs /dev/nvme1n1
sudo mount /dev/nvme1n1 /tmp
sudo chmod 777 /tmp

(confirm it worked with `lsblk` or `df -h`)
